@graph.definition: A seismic method that involves monitoring artificially induced signals.
Remotely sensed spectral imaging obtained from an airborne platform.

A discipline concerned with investigating the Earth from the surface to a depth of several kilometres, specifically aiming to meet the growing demands for natural resources and geo-energies, to respond to the effects of climate change, to provide critical data for civil engineers, and to forecast the effects of natural hazards.

Applied mineralogy is located at the intersection of natural sciences and engineering sciences/technology and deals with the entire line of raw material, from extraction/preparation to processing and disposal, i.e. the application of mineralogical information to understanding and solving problems encountered during exploration and mining, and during processing of ores, concentrates, smelter products, and related materials. It involves characterizing minerals and materials, and interpreting the data with respect to exploration, mineral processing, tailings disposal and treatment, hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, and refining.
The study of human cultures through the recovery and analysis of their material relics.

Archival science, or archival studies, is the study and theory of building and curating archives, i.e. collections of documents, recordings, photographs and various other materials in physical or digital formats, for the purpose of acquiring, evaluating, and accessing recorded materials.

Artificial intelligence (AI), in its broadest sense, is intelligence exhibited by machines, particularly computer systems, i.e. the capability of machines/computers to imitate intelligent human behaviour without being explicitly programmed. By extension, a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and uses learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

The field of science concerned with the study of life in the universe and attempting to solve the mystery of how life emerged on Earth. This includes the search for life beyond Earth, studying environments that could support life as well as investigating interactions between planets and their stars and exploring how this could influence life. Astrobiology is very much an interdisciplinary endeavour encompassing a wide range of scientific fields such as, but not limited to; biology, astronomy, chemistry, geology, atmospheric science, oceanography, and even aeronautical engineering.

The natural sciences that study celestial objects and the phenomena that occur in the cosmos. It uses mathematics, physics, and chemistry to explain their origin and their overall evolution. Objects of interest include planets, moons, stars, nebulae, galaxies, meteoroids, asteroids, and comets or, more generally, everything that originates beyond Earth's atmosphere.
The study of the Earth's atmosphere and its various inner-working physical processes.

The study of the undifferentiated complex of rocks that underlies the rocks of interest in an area, i.e. the crust of the Earth below sedimentary deposits and regolith, extending downward to the Mohorovičić discontinuity. Basement geology may be self-referential in that it is also the study of defining what constitutes basement at regional and local scales, and whether geologically or economically defined.

A geological method of studying sedimentary basins and their potential for energy/mineral commodities, by analysing the sediment fill itself (its composition, primary structures, and internal architecture) to synthesize the basin's geological history/evolution.

A highly interdisciplinary field involving the integration of biology, geology and chemistry, and encompassing the study of the chemical, physical, geological and biological processes and reactions that govern the composition of the natural environment (including the biosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, pedosphere and the lithosphere).

The interdisciplinary study of biology and geology, embracing interactions between the Earth's biosphere and geosphere (i.e. lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and cryosphere). It encompasses the biological aspects of geology, e.g. systematic paleontology, the study of organically influenced sedimentation, or the identification of a concealed rock unit by the type of plant growing at the surface above it.
The natural science that studies life and living organisms, including their physical structure, chemical processes, molecular interactions, physiological mechanisms, development and evolution.

The correlation and age determination of rocks through the use of fossils, i.e. the determination of approximate absolute ages from the distribution of fossil assemblages in strata and primarily based on a number of time scales that related absolute age to the established sequence of (primarily planktonic) fossil events.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the distribution of fossils in the stratigraphic record and the organization of strata into units on the basis of their contained fossils, specifically to date and correlate strata to elucidate Earth's history. In the petroleum industry, biostratigraphy often denotes the use of terrestrial (pollen and spores) and marine (diatoms, foraminifera, nanofossils) microfossils to determine the numerical or relative age and depositional environment of a particular formation, source rock, or reservoir of interest.

Boreheole (or well) logging is the practice of making a detailed record (a well log, report or graph) of the geological materials and formations penetrated by a borehole. The log may be based either on visual inspection of samples brought to the surface (geological logs) or on physical measurements made on these samples or by instruments lowered into the hole (geophysical logs). Some types of geophysical well logs can be done during any phase of a well's history: drilling, completing, producing, or abandoning. Logging is performed in boreholes drilled for the oil and gas, groundwater, mineral and geothermal exploration, as well as part of environmental, geotechnical or geological studies.

Built environment refers to human-made conditions and physical features, and is commonly used in architecture, landscape architecture, urban and regional planning, public health, sociology, and anthropology, among others. These curated spaces provide the setting for human activity and were created to fulfill human desires and needs. The term can refer to a plethora of components including the traditionally associated buildings, cities, public infrastructure, transportation, open space, as well as more conceptual components like farmlands, dammed rivers, wildlife management, and even domesticated animals. Studies of the built environment often highlight the connection between physical space and social consequences. It impacts the environment and how society physically manoeuvers and functions, as well as less tangible aspects of society such as socioeconomic inequity and health.

Studies related to the identification of deep, subsurface geological sites that are suitable to act as reservoirs for the long-term storage of injected CO₂, to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions to the atmosphere.

The science and art of making maps and charts, and the specific use of digital technologies (mapping tools and software) to create seamless geographical displays of data as an image on a computer screen.

Chemostratigraphy, or chemical stratigraphy, is the study of the chemical signatures and their variations within lithological sequences to determine stratigraphic relationships. It includes the element of stratigraphy that deals with chemical signals as recorded in the stratigraphic record to identify spatial–temporal variations in the concentration and distribution of particular elements and isotopes (e.g. carbonate cycles and isotope cycles).
The branch of stratigraphy that deals with the age of strata and their time relations.

Climate change science is the study of changes in the statistical properties of the climate system that persists for several decades or longer — usually at least 30 years. In a broader sense, climate change science also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate. These statistical properties include averages, variability and extremes. Climate change may be due to natural processes, such as changes in the Sun’s radiation, volcanoes activity or internal variability in the climate system, or due to human influences such as changes in the composition of the atmosphere or land use caused by human activity (e.g. burning of fossil fuels, deforestation). In common usage, climate change is often used interchangeably to describe global warming — the ongoing increase in global average temperature — and its effects on Earth's climate system.

Climatology or climate science is the scientific study of Earth's climate, typically defined as weather conditions averaged over a period of at least 30 years. Climate concerns the atmospheric condition during an extended to indefinite period of time; weather is the condition of the atmosphere during a relative brief period of time and is studied by within the field of meteorology.

Coal geology includes the study of the sedimentation of coals and coal-bearing sequences; their stratigraphy, age and geographic distribution; their physical properties, including coal rank and quality, and the associated classification of coals; their hydrogeological characteristics; contained gases, and the contribution of coal deposits (amongst other rock types) to accumulations of oil and natural gas.

Collection management refers to the development, storage, and preservation of cultural and natural property, as well as objects of contemporary culture (including contemporary art, literature, technology, and documents) in museums, libraries, archives and private collections. The primary goal of collections management is to meet the needs of the individual collector or collecting institution's mission statement, while also ensuring the long-term safety and sustainability of the objects within the collector's care. Collections management consists primarily of the administrative responsibilities associated with collection development and maintenance (information, preservation, movement, documentation, exhibitions and access processes), and is closely related to collections care, that is the physical preservation for posterity of items in the collections.

@graph.prefLabel: computational modelling and simulation in earth sciences
@graph.definition: A multidisciplinary field that combines geoscience with advanced mathematical modelling, simulation, numerical modelling, visualization and data analysis techniques. Computational geoscience uses large-scale, nonlinear models that couple multiple physical, chemical, and biological processes across various length and time scales to improve our understanding of the Earth system and its complexities, addressing geoscience grand challenges, and providing decision-support tools for geoscience policy makers and industry. The emergence of computation as a powerful tool for prediction and decision-making in the geosciences is driven by advances in the rapid expansion of our ability to instrument and observe the Earth, sustained improvements in computational models and solution methods for complex geoscience systems, and the relentless growth in computing power.

Computed tomography (CT) is a method for imaging and analysing features in rock, mineral or soil specimens in three dimensions using energy attenuation of photons (X-ray tomography), neutrons (neutron tomography), ultrasonic waves (ultrasound tomography), or using magnetic resonance (magnetic resonance imaging). The detected data are used to reconstruct the internal distribution of materials.

The study of conventional (carbonate and clastic) petroleum systems that contain hydrocarbon accumulations and are defined as those where buoyant forces keep hydrocarbons in place below the sealing caprocks and permit petroleum (oil and/or natural gas) to flow readily from reservoirs into wellbores; i.e. are accessible by standard oilfield techniques and typically do not require advanced drilling, completions, and reservoir stimulation methods. Studies of conventional reservoir include assessment of rock properties, particularly porosity, permeability and compressibility, and of the timing and mechanism of trap formation, as petroleum source rocks, reservoir rocks, impermeable caprocks/seals must form in a favourable sequence to allow accumulation in reservoir rocks (following petroleum generation in source rocks and its ensuing migration therefrom).
Studies related to the measurement of petrophysical properties in samples collected in the field or from drillcores.

Core logging is the systematic recording and analysis of drillcores, to provide geological understanding of the materials penetrated by a borehole, and to assist in resource estimation. It employs different methods and techniques to characterize subsurface minerals, rocks and formations, as well as their geometry, structure and relationships relative to depth — by observation, measurements and analysis. Although a large proportion of drilling is carried out in the pursuit of mineral and energy resources, core logging is also a critical component of other investigations (e.g. stratigraphic, geotechnical, etc.).
Spectral imaging (typically hyperspectral) of rock samples such as core.

The study of crystals, i.e. of homogeneous, solid bodies of chemical element, compound, or isomorphous mixture, having regularly repeating atomic arrangement that may be outwardly expressed by plane faces. It comprises studies of crystal growth, structure, physical properties and their classification by form. It includes optical crystallography (the branch dealing with the optical properties of crystals) and structural crystallography (the study of the internal arrangement and spacing of atoms and molecules composing crystalline solids).

The process of extracting and discovering patterns in large datasets involving methods at the intersection of machine learning, statistics, and database systems. Data mining is an interdisciplinary subfield of computer science and statistics with an overall goal of extracting information (with intelligent methods) from a dataset and transforming the information into a comprehensible structure for further use.

Data science is an interdisciplinary academic field that uses statistics, scientific computing, scientific methods, processes, algorithms, and systems to extract or extrapolate knowledge and insights from noisy, structured, and unstructured data. Data management is the practice of collecting, organizing, protecting, and storing an organization’s data so it can be analysed for business decisions or provided to third parties.

Deep learning is a subset of machine learning methods that utilize neural networks for representation learning, i.e. simulate the complex decision-making power of the human brain. The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and is centered around stacking artificial neurons into layers and 'training' them to process data. The adjective 'deep' refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.'
The study of annual growth rings of trees for dating of the recent past.

Descriptive mineralogy includes a description of the crystallographic, general physical and chemical characters of each mineral species, and provides an account of their mode of occurrence and characteristic associations. For minerals possessing an economic value, it includes a brief statement of their uses and industrial applications.

Digital heritage is the use of digital media in the service of understanding and preserving cultural or natural heritage; more specifically, according to the Charter on the Preservation of Digital Heritage of UNESCO, digital heritage is defined as embracing 'cultural, educational, scientific and administrative resources, as well as technical, legal, medical and other kinds of information created digitally, or converted into digital form from existing analogue resources'. The main goal of the digitization of cultural and natural heritage is to enable the preservation and permanent access of current and future generations to culturally and scientific important objects at all scales.
Downhole, or borehole, geophysical surveys measure the physical properties of rocks along a subsurface drillhole.

Studies related to and associated with the technological advancement of drilling operations, aimed at mitigating the drilling operational deficiencies and instabilities that could hinder operational performance activities and the economic part of drilling development with great effort to minimize their environmental footprint. It includes geoscience-related results obtained during the testing of improved or emerging technologies.

The science of designing as well as safely and economically making a hole (also called a well or wellbore) from the surface through a rock (or formation) to target potential energy or mineral resources in the subsurface and facilitate the evaluation of the geological intervals penetrated.

Earth and Space Science Informatics (ESSI) encompasses a broad field that addresses data management practices, computation and analysis, and hardware and software infrastructure. It involves collaborative work to assess, design, implement, and promote practices and tools that enable effective data management, discovery, integration, and reuse for interdisciplinary work in Earth and space science (ESS) disciplines.

An all-embracing term for all fields of natural sciences related to the planet Earth. It is occasionally used as a synonym for geology or geological sciences, but this usage is misleading because in its wider scope earth science may be considered to include such subjects as meteorology, physical oceanography, soil chemistry, and agronomy.

The study of Earth as an integrated system, particularly the physical, chemical, biological and human interactions that determine the past, current and future states of the Earth. Earth System Science is the study of the interactions and interdependencies within and between the Earth’s various physical, chemical and biological “spheres” (lithosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, atmosphere, cryosphere), and the impacts that changes to any of these may have for the entire Earth System (including humans).
A branch of biology concerning interactions among organisms and their biophysical environment, which includes both biotic and abiotic components.
A discipline that investigates and promotes understanding of economic and policy issues associated with the production and use of mineral and energy commodities.

@graph.prefLabel: electrical and electromagnetic methods in geophysics
@graph.definition: Geophysical methods that involve the use of electrical and electromagnetic fields to study the subsurface properties of the Earth. These methods exploit the interaction between electromagnetic waves and the electrical conductivity, permittivity, and magnetic susceptibility of subsurface materials.

The use of geophysical methods to detect and image different electrical properties of the subsurface, by measuring naturally occurring (i.e. passive) or artificially introduced (i.e. active) voltage potentials, electrical currents, and/or electromagnetic fields. Subsurface electrical properties can be measured galvanically via direct electrode connection to the ground or inductively via electromagnetic field induction through the subsurface. The Electrical resistivity technique is used to determine the resistivity of subsurface materials, the Induced Polarization (IP) technique is used to measure the decay of voltage in the ground, and the Self-Potential (SP) technique looks for natural voltage sources underground.

The use of geophysical methods to detect and image the electrical properties of the subsurface by inducing electromagnetic (EM) energy within the subsurface (i.e. propagation of electromagnetic fields composed of an alternating electric intensity and magnetizing force) and measuring the response of earth materials.

The measurement and modelling of the elevation of geographic locations, i.e. of the height above or below a fixed reference point, most commonly a reference geoid (a mathematical model of the Earth's sea level as an equipotential gravitational surface).

The search for deposits of useful fossil fuels and energy resources. It includes multidisciplinary approaches, including geological studies, remote sensing, photogeology, geophysical and geochemical methods, and both surface and below ground investigations.

A branch of geology that focuses on the study of conventional, non-conventional and renewable natural resources used for energy production, i.e. including fossil fuels (like coal, oil, and natural gas), renewable energy resources (like wind, solar, and geothermal), and nuclear resources. This field involves understanding the formation, distribution, extraction, and environmental impacts of these energy resource.

The practice of using natural science, mathematics, and the (engineering) design process to solve technical problems, increase efficiency and productivity, and improve systems. More specifically, 'the creative application of scientific principles to design or develop structures, machines, apparatus, or manufacturing processes, or works utilizing them singly or in combination; or to construct or operate the same with full cognizance of their design; or to forecast their behaviour under specific operating conditions; all as respects an intended function, economics of operation and safety to life and property' (American Engineers' Council for Professional Development).

The application of geology to engineering study for the purpose of assuring that the geological factors regarding the location, design, construction, operation and maintenance of engineering works are recognized and accounted for. Engineering geologists provide geological and geotechnical recommendations, analysis, and design associated with human development and various types of structures. The realm of the engineering geologist is essentially in the area of Earth-structure interactions, or investigation of how the Earth or Earth processes impact human-made structures and human activities.

A professional engineering discipline related to environmental science that encompasses broad scientific topics like chemistry, biology, ecology, geology, hydraulics, hydrology, microbiology, and mathematics to create solutions that will protect and also improve the health of living organisms and improve the quality of the environment.
The study of the effect on humans (and life in general) of the distribution and interrelations of the chemical elements and radioactivity among surficial rocks, water, air, and biota.

A multidisciplinary, applied science concerned with the practical application of the principles of geology in the solving of environmental problems created by humans and their activities. Environmental geology is specifically concerned with Earth processes, Earth resources, and engineering properties of Earth materials that are relevant to: 1) the protection of human health and natural ecosystems from adverse biochemical and/or geochemical reactions to naturally occurring chemicals or to chemicals and chemical compounds released into the environment by human activities; and 2) the protection of life, safety, and well-being human from natural processes, such as floods, hurricanes, earthquakes and landslides, through land-use planning.
Environmental resource management or environmental management is the management of the interaction and impact of human societies on the environment (and not the management of the environment itself).

An interdisciplinary academic field that integrates physical, biological and information sciences to the study of the environment, and the solution of environmental problems. It specifically addresses: (1) social and political decision making and policy setting relative to the environment or environmental ethics, (2) the planning and management of natural and human resources with an emphasis on the social and political aspects, and (3) legal and regulatory aspects of environmental protection activities carried out by the government under its powers.

Evolutionary paleontology (also called evolutionary paleobiology) is paleontology’s intersection with evolutionary biology. Its main aims are to reconstruct the history of life on Earth (historical paleontology, phylogeny) and the patterns and causes of evolutionary change and extinction (biological and physical processes and unique historical events).

Experimental mineralogy and petrology are the Earth science disciplines that model or simulate mineralogical, petrological, and geochemical processes within the laboratory in order to understand the physical and chemical properties of minerals, rocks, melts, and fluids and their interactions.

A discipline that employs high-pressure, high-temperature apparatus to investigate the geochemistry and phase relations of natural or synthetic materials at elevated pressures and temperatures. Experiments are particularly useful for investigating rocks of the lower crust and upper mantle that rarely survive the journey to the surface in pristine condition. They are also one of the prime sources of information about completely inaccessible rocks, such as those in the Earth's lower mantle and in the mantles of the other terrestrial planets and the Moon. The work of experimental petrologists has laid a foundation on which modern understanding of igneous and metamorphic processes has been built.

Geochemistry that is specifically focused on identification of mineralization, its dispersion haloes, alteration patterns and distribution. It specifically focuses on the enrichment or depletion of certain elements (including pathfinders) having a genetic affinity to the target mineralization. Exploration geochemistry is typical of exploration stages aiming at locating mineral deposits but also applies to the near-mine exploration conducted to further locate and delineate resources.

A planetary science discipline concerned with the geology of celestial bodies such as the planets and their moons, asteroids, comets, and meteorites, i.e. a science that applies principles and techniques of geology, geochemistry, and geophysics to the study of the nature, origin, and history of the condensed matter and gases in the solar system and beyond. It includes a) remote-sensing observations and in situ manned exploration of other planetary bodies, such as the Moon and Mars, Venus, Mercury, and 'earthlike' or 'rocky' satellite moons of the giant planets; b) the study of the chemistry, mineralogy (cosmic mineralogy), and history of objects that occur on the Earth but are of known or possible extraterrestrial origin (such as meteorites and tektites) or that are returned to the Earth (such as lunar samples); and c) the study of the effects of extraterrestrial processes (such as meteorite impact, solar energy changes, and tides) on the Earth in the present and past.
Analysis of the chemical and physical properties of fluids extracted from rocks and geological materials in the subsurface.

The study of the composition, stratigraphy and petrology of liquids and/or gases contained within tiny (usually in the order of micrometres) cavities formed either by the entrapment in crystal irregularities of fluids from which the mineral/rock crystallized, or by any process after the crystallization of the host mineral is essentially complete (e.g. healing of fractures within a crystal).

The study of tiny encapsulations of fluids that trap oil, gas, water and solid phases in minerals and rocks to determine parameters such as temperature, pressure, salinity, density and depth of trapping — thereby providing direct information about the conditions of formation. In the case of hydrocarbon exploration, these studies are conducted to assess the fluid history of the rock/sedimentary basin and the prevailing thermal conditions, to determine whether oil and gas are likely to be found at a particular location, as well as the source and type of hydrocarbon present.

The study of trace evidence provided by Earth materials that is used to answer questions raised by the legal system, specifically the potential to link a suspect to a particular crime or a particular crime scene.

Functional morphology is an interpretative subdiscipline of paleobiology, and is the study of the form, structure and function of organisms or parts of organisms in terms of the biological roles that they play (i.e. function and behaviour).
The science and study of natural and artificial gemstones, including their source, description, geology, origin, identification, grading and appraisal.

The empirical investigation of the principles that control mineral formation in the geological environment, including mineral paragenesis and the physical and chemical parameters of formation and alteration (mineral ontogenesis); the quantitative geothermometric, geobarometric, and chemical studies of mineral-forming systems; and experimental modelling of crystal growth in the laboratory.

A multi-disciplinary approach that uses the techniques and subject matter of geography, geology, geophysics and other Earth sciences to examine topics which inform archeological and chronological knowledge and thought. Geoarcheologists study the natural physical processes that affect archeological sites such as geomorphology, the formation of sites through geological processes and the effects on buried sites and artifacts post-deposition.

An interdisciplinary study of life sciences and Earth sciences, i.e. the field of scientific research that explores the interactions between the physical Earth and the biosphere to investigate the evolutionary interconnectedness of life and Earth — it deals with process (how organisms affect the Earth and vice versa), as well as history (how the Earth and life have changed together). There is considerable overlap with the fields of ecology, evolutionary biology, microbiology, paleontology, and particularly soil science and biogeochemistry. Geobiology applies the principles and methods of biology, geology and soil science to the study of the ancient history of the co-evolution of life and Earth as well as the role of life in the modern world. Geobiological studies tend to be focused on micro-organisms, and on the role that life plays in altering the chemical and physical environment of the pedosphere, which exists at the intersection of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and/or cryosphere. It differs from biogeochemistry in that the focus is on processes and organisms over space and time rather than on global chemical cycles.

The study of the distribution and amounts of the chemical elements in minerals, ores, rocks, soils, water, the atmosphere on Earth and within solid bodies of the solar system, including the distribution, circulation and abundance of elements (and their ions and isotopes), molecules, minerals, rocks and fluids.
Geochemical data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geochemistry.

The science of dating and determining the time sequence of events in the history of the Earth, i.e. the study of the relative or numerical/absolute age of rocks, minerals and fossils. Numerical age is the measurement of age in years ('numerical' is preferred to 'absolute' ages, as the latter typically have some amount of error and are inexact) whereas relative age, in contrast, is the approximate age of rocks, fossils or minerals made by determining the age of the material relative to the age of and relationships with other surrounding material.

The practice of protecting and managing sites and landscapes which have value for their geology or geomorphology. The identification (cf. geoheritage) and conservation of these geological sites is through government agencies and local geological societies. The designation of these sites is done through an analysis of the site, and the production of proper management infrastructure. The principles of geoconservation are to create a means of protection for the sites and assess their value to the geological and wider community. Typically the conservation of geodiversity at a site or within a landscape takes place alongside that of biodiversity.

The science of measuring and representing the geometry (size and shape) of the Earth and the precise location of points on its surface; it includes the determination of the gravitational field of the Earth and the study of temporal variations such as Earth tides, polar motion, and rotation of the Earth.

A subfield of geophysics dealing with the forces and processes of the interior of the Earth. It applies physics, chemistry and mathematics to the understanding of how mantle convection leads to plate tectonics and geological phenomena such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting and so on. It also attempts to probe the internal activities of the Earth by measuring magnetic fields, gravity, and seismic waves, as well as the mineralogy of rocks and their isotopic composition.

The branch of ethics that considers the interaction of human activity with the physical world and with the practice of the Earth Sciences. It comprises scientific research and philosophical reflection on the values governing human behaviours wherever they interact with the Earth system, including the ethical, social, and cultural implications of the activities of geoscientists when conducting scientific and technological research and practice.

Geographic Information Science (GIScience) is the basic research field that seeks to redefine geographic concepts and their use in the context of geographic information systems. GIScience also examines the impacts of GIS on individuals and society, and the influences of society on GIS. GIScience re-examines some of the most fundamental themes in traditional spatially oriented fields such as geography, cartography, and geodesy, while incorporating more recent developments in cognitive and information science

The study of adverse geological conditions capable of causing widespread damage or loss of property and life. These hazards are geological and environmental conditions and involve long-term or short-term geological processes. Geohazards can be relatively small features (e.g. geyser) but can also attain huge dimensions (e.g. submarine or surface landslide) and affect local and regional socio-economics to a large extent (e.g. tsunamis, volcanic eruptions).

The identification of global, national, state-wide, or local features of geology (such as igneous, metamorphic, sedimentary, stratigraphic, structural, geochemical, mineralogical, paleontological, geomorphical, pedological, and hydrological attributes) that are: (a) intrinsically important or culturally important sites; (b) offer information or insights into the formation or evolution of the Earth, or into the history of science, or (c) that can be used for research, teaching, or reference. Geoheritage is inextricably linked to geoconservation, for the preservation of these sites for posterity.

The application of modern information technology/computational systems to organize, preserve, and distribute geoscience data, and to facilitate and advance their analysis, i.e. the science and technology that develop and use data, software, and computing facilities in the cyberinfrastructure ecosystem to address the needs of geosciences and related branches of science and engineering.
Geoinformatics data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geoinformatics.

The process of making observations in the field, as well as collecting and studying samples of Earth's materials to understand the geology of an area, and more specifically to produce a diagram, drawing, or other graphical representation of the area in question, by means of signs and/or symbols and with the means of orientation indicated, so that the relative position and size of each feature on the map corresponds to its correct geographical situation according to a definite and established scale and projection.
The applied science of creating computerized representations of portions of the Earth’s subsurface based on geophysical and geological observations made on and below the Earth surface.

An Earth science concerned with the planet Earth and the rocks/materials of which it is made, the processes that act on these materials and by which these change over time, the products formed, to understand the history of the planet and its life forms since its origin, and including the study of physical forces that act on the Earth, the chemistry of its constituent materials, and the biology of its past inhabitants as revealed by fossils. Geology can also include the study of the solid features of any terrestrial planet or natural satellite such as Mars or the Moon. Modern geology significantly overlaps all other earth sciences, including hydrology and the atmospheric sciences, and so is treated as one major aspect of integrated Earth system science and planetary science.
Geological data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geology.

The development and application of mathematical methods and principles to process geoscientific data for geological feature imaging or for understanding (modelling) geological processes, from the atomic to planetary scale, across the entire spectrum of geoscientific disciplines.

A professional engineering discipline that focuses on spatial information (i.e. information that has a location) to design, develop, and operate systems for collecting and analysing spatial information about the land, the oceans, natural resources, and man-made features.
Geomatic engineering data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geomatics engineering.

The discipline concerned with the collection, distribution, storage, analysis, processing, presentation of geographic data or geographic information, as well as the products, services and tools involved in the collection, integration and management of geographic (geospatial) data.

A branch at the intersection of geology and engineering that embraces the fundamentals of structural geology and a knowledge of the response, or strain, of earth materials (soil and rocks) to deformation or changes caused by the application of stress and/or strain energy, as well as the application of such studies to solve engineering problems in the design of engineering works.

The practice of combining geology or geostatistics with extractive metallurgy, to create a spatially or geologically based predictive model to optimize the efficiency of mineral processing plants. Geometallurgy specifically maps the 3D variability in petrophysical and mineralogical properties of an entire orebody, to define domains that require different mining and metallurgical processing techniques, to maximize recovery of the saleable product at minimum cost.

The scientific study of the general configuration of the Earth's surface, i.e. of the origin and evolution of topographic and bathymetric features created by physical, chemical or biological processes operating at or near the Earth's surface. Specifically studies dealing with the classification, description, nature, origin, processes, and development of present landforms and their relationships to underlying structures, and of the history of geological changes as recorded by these surface features. Geomorphology overlaps in meaning with physiography, with 'physiography' commonly regarded as a more descriptive and 'geomorphology' as a more interpretative study of landforms.
The study of fluid dynamics of naturally occurring flows, such as lava flows, oceans, and planetary atmospheres, on Earth and other planets.

The applied science of creating computerized representations of the Earth based on geophysical and geological observations and their interpretation. Geophysical models are a simplified concept and/or visualization of how one or more physical properties are distributed within the Earth. They are generally an object, a halfspace, 1D (layered earth), 2D, or 3D.

A natural science concerned with the physical processes and physical properties of the Earth and its surrounding space environment, and the use of quantitative methods for their analysis. It includes several disciplines focusing on the study of the Earth's electrical, gravitational and magnetic fields and the propagation of elastic (seismic) waves within it.
Geophysical data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geophysics.

A variety of practices that transmit scientific ideas, methods, knowledge, and research to non-expert audiences in an accessible, understandable, or useful way, with a particular focus on subjects related to Earth's physical features, processes, and systems.
The developing of tools that promote geoscience data integration and synthesis, and also facilitate quantitative cross-disciplinary access to data.

Also known as Earth science education, it is the study of Earth's physical features, processes, and systems, as well as the natural and human-induced events that shape it. It encompasses a wide range of disciplines, including geology, oceanography, meteorology, climatology, environmental science, and more. Geoscience education plays a crucial role in fostering scientific literacy, environmental awareness, and sustainable development, as well as in preparing future generations of geoscientists, policymakers, educators, and citizens.

@graph.prefLabel: geospatial information systems and geospatial data modelling
@graph.definition: The application of geographic information systems (GIS), i.e. an integrated computer hardware and software, to store, manage, analyse, edit, output, visualize and model geographic data.

A branch of statistics focusing on spatial or spatiotemporal datasets, developed originally to predict probability distributions of ore grades for mining operations, but now applied also in petroleum geology, hydrogeology, hydrology, meteorology, oceanography, geochemistry, geometallurgy, geography, forestry, environmental control, landscape ecology, soil science and agriculture.
Engineering applied to the capture and storage of materials (commonly liquids and gases, and especially greenhouse gases) or energy (commonly gas or heat) in the subsurface of the Earth.

A field at the intersection of geology and engineering dealing with the study of the engineering behaviours of earth materials to address engineering problems. It uses soil and rock mechanics for practical applications in, amongst other disciplines, mining engineering, petroleum engineering, coastal engineering, and onshore/offshore construction.

The study of the accessible thermal energy stored within the Earth's crust, in order to access and extract it. It includes studies of related geological systems and the methods, materials and operations used in the production of energy.

A subdiscipline of geophysics that studies the thermal state of the interior of the solid Earth and of the thermal properties of Earth materials. Components of geothermal research are temperature distribution within the Earth, terrestrial heat flow, heat generation, thermal properties of Earth materials, volcanology, geothermal energy, hydrocarbon formation, fluid flow, and permafrost. Cf. temperature studies.
The study of heatflow and radioactive activity within the Earth.
Tourism that sustains or enhances the distinctive geographical character of a place — its environment, heritage, aesthetics, culture, and the well-being of its residents​.

The scientific discipline concerned with all aspects of ice and solid water on landmasses. It deals with the structure and properties of glaciers and ice sheets, their physical properties, formation and distribution, the dynamics of ice flow, and the interactions of ice accumulation with climate.

Grade control is the process aiming to maximize the value of ore mined and fed into the mill. This is commonly achieved by systematic, closely-spaced drilling to check the quality and grade of the ore while mining is underway. Drillhole data, other sampling data and geological mapping can all be used to delineate ore for mining purposes, thus ‘controlling the grade’ of feedstock to the mill.
The measure of changes in gravity due to variations in the density of the rocks to remotely map the distribution of different rock types and the structure of rocks in the Earth's subsurface.
The study of variations (anomalies) in the Earth's gravity field via measurements of the spatial gradient of gravitational acceleration.

Spectral imaging obtained in the field or at a mine site, especially using portable devices (e.g. pXRF); applications include characterization of outcrops and materials, mine wall face mapping, and ore grade classification.

Heritage conservation seeks to sustain the values of heritage (including both natural and cultural heritage) landscapes, places and objects, individually and collectively, so that the community and visitors can continue to appreciate, experience and learn from them and about them, and so that they can be passed on to future generations. More specifically, this field refers to the more practical or applied aspects of site or object restoration, preventative activities, and/or remedial treatments.

The study of collections, their heritage values and the ways of presenting their significance (interpretation) as a 'means of communicating ideas and feelings which help people enrich their understanding and appreciation of their world and their role within it' (Australian Heritage Commission).

@graph.prefLabel: heritage tourism, visitor and audience studies
@graph.definition: Heritage tourism is a form of non-business travel whereby tourists engage with the heritage, tangible and intangible, moveable and immovable, abstract or concrete, natural or cultural, of a region through activities, experiences, and purchases which facilitate a connection to the people, objects, and places of the past (including geological sites) associated with the locations being visited. Studies associated with this field refer to the management of such sites, the evaluation of the impact of visitors and the assessment of tourist satisfaction and emotional experiences during the visit.

Studies related to the identification, collection, curation, conservation, interpretation, use and management of cultural and natural heritage, by examining the variety of locations through which this happens such as objects and collections, museums, heritage places, intangible cultural heritage, and international heritage practice.

@graph.prefLabel: heritage, archive and museum studies not elsewhere classified
@graph.definition: Heritage, archive and museum studies not otherwise described by other sub-categories of heritage, archive and museum studies.

@graph.prefLabel: heritage, archive and museum studies not elsewhere classified
@graph.definition: Studies related to the identification, collection, curation, conservation, interpretation, use and management of cultural and natural heritage, by examining the variety of locations through which this happens such as objects and collections, museums, heritage places, intangible cultural heritage, and international heritage practice

The branch of geology concerned with the reconstruction and comprehension of the geological history of the Earth, i.e. the evolution of the Earth and its life forms from its origins to the present day. This discipline examines the vastness of geological time, measured in billions of years, and investigates changes in the Earth (gradual and sudden) over this deep time. It focuses on geological processes, such as plate tectonics, that have changed the Earth's surface and subsurface over time and the use of methods including stratigraphy, structural geology, paleontology, and sedimentology to tell the sequence of these events. It also focuses on the evolution of life during different time periods in the geologic time scale. Not to be confused with history of geology.

That branch of the history of science that documents the development of geological knowledge, including the history of observations of geological features, the history of theories to explain their origin, and the history of the organization and development of geological institutions and societies. The biographical study of geologists is included. Not to be confused with historical geology.

Collectively, the study of practices, items and places designated as significant, including the investigation and interpretation of past human events (history), the identification, conservation and presentation of significant places, processes and items (heritage), and the study of human cultures through recovered artefacts or relics (archeology). Although history and archeology imply the interpretation of human culture, heritage and museum studies can be applied to concepts of both natural (abiotic or biotic) or cultural significance.

The study of a group of individuals involved in persistent social interaction or of a large social group sharing the same spatial or social territory, typically subject to the same political authority and dominant cultural expectations.

The chemistry of ground and surface waters, particularly the relationships between the chemical characteristics and quality of waters and the areal and regional geology. On a broader scale, the science that uses the tools and principles of chemistry to explain the mechanisms behind major geological systems such as the Earth's crust and its oceans.

The area of geology that deals with the distribution and movement of subsurface water (i.e. groundwater) in the soil and rocks of the Earth's crust, and with related geological aspects of surface waters.

The study of the fossilized tracks, trails, burrows and excavations made by animals and more broadly the study of bioturbation, which is the reworking of sediment by animals. Ichnofossils or trace fossils are used to interpret paleoecological aspects of sedimentary environments.

The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of igneous rocks, i.e. those that are formed from magma. It relies heavily on the use of chemistry, chemical methods, and phase diagrams.

Information and computing (or computer) science (ICS) or computer and information science (CIS) (or sciences) is a field that emphasizes both computing and informatics, upholding the strong association between the fields of information sciences and computer sciences and treating computers as a tool rather than a field. Information science is primarily concerned with gathering, storing, disseminating, sharing and protecting any and all forms of information — it is a broad field, covering a myriad of different areas but is often referenced alongside computer science because of the incredibly useful nature of computers and computer programs in helping those studying and doing research in the field, particularly in helping to analyse data and in spotting patterns too broad for a human to intuitively perceive.

Information management (IM) is the appropriate and optimized capture, storage, retrieval, and use of information. It may be personal information management or organizational. Information management for organizations concerns a cycle of organizational activity: the acquisition of information from one or more sources, the custodianship and the distribution of that information to those who need it, and its ultimate disposal through archiving or deletion and extraction.

An information system (IS) is a formal, integrated set of components for the collection, storage and processing of data, aimed at providing information, contributing to knowledge and delivering digital products that facilitate decision-making.
The broader field for the study of the chemistry of inorganic rocks, minerals, and other Earth materials that are not currently or once living.

The part of cultural heritage that deals with items that have no physical existence, such as past and current traditions or living expressions inherited from our ancestors and passed on to our descendants (e.g. oral traditions, performing arts, social practices, rituals, festive events), knowledge and practices concerning nature and the universe, or the knowledge and skills to produce traditional crafts.

The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of organisms of the 'invertebrate' phyla, i.e. of those animals that lack notochords (non-vertebrates).

The application of natural variations in the relative abundances of isotopes of various elements, measured by isotope-ratio mass spectrometry, to reveal information about the ages of rock, air or water bodies, or processes of mixing between them.
The determination of the relative and absolute concentrations of the elements and their isotopes in the Earth and on Earth's surface.
Spectral imaging and mapping obtained under controlled laboratory conditions, e.g. for the qualitative and quantitative mineral identification and phase relationships.

Land-use and environmental planning involves the regulation and commitment of land-use, as to how the landscape is used (whether for food production, forestry, nature conservation, water storage, urban development, mining, etc.), to ensure the most efficient, effective and beneficial management and utilization of resources, and to provide optimal environmental and social outcomes.
The study of the complete chemical composition of whole rocks, considering the main and trace elements, but also isotopes.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the description and systematic organization of the rocks of the Earth's crust into distinctive named units based on the lithological character of the rocks and their stratigraphic relations. In the petroleum industry, lithostratigraphy specifically refers to the study and correlation of strata to elucidate Earth's history on the basis of their lithology or the nature of the well log response, mineral content, grain size, texture, and colour of rocks.
A comprehensive study of the geological and geographical features of a subdivision of or area within a region (in this context defined as an area of land that has common natural features).

The acquisition of a continuous record as a function of depth, usually graphic and plotted to scale, of observations, analyses or measurements made on the geological materials of the section exposed in a borehole or of the sample (drillcore or cuttings) obtained from it.

Machine learning (ML) is the field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalize to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

The study of the Earth's magnetic field via non-invasive geophysical methods which measure perturbations in the Earth’s magnetic field caused by magnetic minerals in crustal rocks, specifically to image anomalies caused by source bodies within the subsurface.

The study of physical phenomena associated with moving electricity in conductive rocks or the permanent magnetic effects of naturally magnetic rocks, and the study of natural remanent magnetization of Earth materials in order to determine the direction, and indirectly intensity, of the Earth's magnetic field in the geological past.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the magnetic characteristics of rock units. Specifically the geophysical correlation technique used to date sedimentary rocks lacking fossils and volcanic sequences by collecting oriented samples at measured intervals throughout a section and measuring the characteristic remanent magnetization.

Magnetotellurics (MT) is a passive geophysical method used to infer the Earth's subsurface electrical resistivity/conductivity from measurements of natural variations of geomagnetic and geoelectric field at the Earth's surface, i.e. the use of natural electromagnetic signals to image subsurface electrical conductivity structure through electromagnetic induction.
The study of the history and structure of the ocean floor. It involves geophysical, geochemical, sedimentological and paleontological investigations of the ocean floor and coastal zone.

Maritime archeology (also known as marine archeology) is a discipline of archeology that specifically studies human interaction with the sea, lakes and rivers through the study of associated physical remains, be they vessels, shore-side facilities, port-related structures, cargoes, human remains and submerged landscapes.
The technical aspects related to the protection and care of materials to avoid their physical deterioration while actively ensuring their preservation for posterity.

An interdisciplinary scientific field studying the influence of natural geological factors on human and animal health. Broadly, medical geology studies exposure to or deficiency of trace elements and minerals (the distribution of trace elements as related to nutrition, or the geographic patterns of disease); inhalation of ambient and anthropogenic mineral dusts and volcanic emissions; transportation, modification and concentration of organic compounds; the occurrence of toxic elements in unusual quantities in parts of the Earth's crust; and exposure to radionuclides, microbes and pathogens.

The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of metamorphic rocks, i.e. those derived from the transformation of existing rocks into new types. It relies heavily on the use of chemistry, chemical methods, and phase diagrams.

The systematic study of fossil microbialites and other evidence of/for microbes and microbially influenced features in the geological record, focussing on their morphology, classification, and environmental and biostratigraphic significance. Microbial paleobiology commonly intersects with disciplines such as geobiology, astrobiology and biostratigraphy, and is commonly employed in studies concerned with the origins of life on Earth.

The systematic study of microfossils (i.e. fossils too small to be observed without the aid of a microscope), their morphology, classification, and environmental and biostratigraphic significance. Microfossils can represent the remains, or partial remains, of a wide range of organism kingdoms and phyla, but palynomorphs are generally excluded.

The application of geological theory to warfare and the peacetime practices of the military. Military geologists are used for terrain analysis (geomorphology, soil science), engineering (building of roads and airfields), and the identification of resources (e.g. water supply or construction materials), and to research the effects of military practices on Earth's and planets' geology. The peacetime application of military geology includes the building of infrastructure, typically during local emergencies or foreign peacekeeping deployments.

The study of the chemical composition of minerals, i.e. of naturally occurring inorganic element or compound with a defined chemical composition and crystal structure, i.e. having a periodically repeating arrangement of atoms and characteristic chemical composition, resulting in distinctive physical properties. It includes the analysis of the major, minor, trace and isotope elemental composition of a mineral, as well as the bonding of these elements in the mineral’s crystal structure.

Studies related to the search for deposits of useful minerals. It may include geological reconnaissance, geological mapping, remote sensing analysis, geophysical and geochemical methods, and both surface and subsurface (e.g. drilling and underground) investigations. Also studies to establish the nature of a known mineral deposit, in preparatory to development and exploitation; in this sense exploration goes beyond discovery, and is a broader term than prospecting.

The study of concentrations of inorganic, naturally occurring, typically solid, typically non-renewable materials that are of intrinsic economic interest in or on the Earth's crust in such form, quality and quantity that there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction. It includes the study of mineral systems, i.e. the combination of geological processes that are required to form and preserve an ore deposit. Also included is the characterization of orebodies (e.g. quantification of physical properties and chemical properties, and delineation of volumes, grades and geometry), and of limitations to the development and exploitation of mineral occurrences.

Understanding the combination of geologic processes that are required to form and preserve ore deposits at all scales. It recognises seven critical geological processes: source of mineralizing fluid, source of metals, fluid pathway, thermal gradient, energy source, structural focusing of fluids, and chemical or physical trap for metal precipitation.
The scientific study of minerals, their formation, occurrence, physical and chemical properties, composition, and classification.
The scientific study of the chemistry, crystal structure, and physical properties of minerals and mineralized artifacts.

Studies related to the process of extracting metallic or non-metallic mineral deposits from the Earth. The term may also include the preliminary treatment of extracted materials, e.g. cleaning or sizing.

The application of molecular analytical techniques to fossil or subfossil material in order to test for the presence of original biomolecules. These molecules may be proteins, DNA, carbohydrates or lipids, or their diagenetic products.

A branch of paleontology that deals with the form and structure of organisms based on their fossil remains; especially a study of the forms, relations, and phylogenetic development of biological structures apart from their functions.

The study of natural phenomena that might have a negative effect on humans or the environment, specifically hazards encompassing geological and meteorological phenomena such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires, cyclonic storms, floods, droughts, avalanches and landslides, as well as phenomena such as natural radioactivity.
The study of the post-Miocene structures and structural history of the Earth's crust.
The branch of isotope geochemistry focusing on non-radiogenic (or stable) isotope systems, i.e. those where a nuclide is not known to undergo radioactive decay.

The branch of geochronology / isotope geochemistry focusing on non-radiogenic (or stable) isotope systems, i.e. those where a nuclide is not known to undergo radioactive decay, to determine the numerical age of suitable geological materials.
The study of the ocean, including its physical, chemical, biologic, and geological aspects.
The study of economically valuable minerals (ores) in the Earth's crust, including their formation, distribution, and extraction methods.
The microscopic study of metallic ores using reflected light.

The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of ore minerals, i.e. of naturally occurring minerals that contain valuable elements or minerals in sufficient quantities to be economically mined and processed for their desired metal or mineral content.

The study of the role of processes and compounds that are derived from living or once-living organisms, i.e. the study of the transformation undergone by organic matter of all types, whether of biological or man-made origin, in the Earth System. The transformations involved vary from those mediated by biological processes involved in the production of living tissue and the operation of food-chains, to those controlled by temperature and pressure at depth in the crust. Photochemical processes in the atmosphere and hydrosphere can also be important in controlling the environmental behaviour of some organic compounds.
Organic petrology involves the study of organic matter (OM) in rocks, including its origin and thermal maturity due to burial within the Earth's crust.

That branch of paleontology that treats the geographic distribution of organisms in past geological time, especially with regard to the ecologic, climatologic, and evolutionary factors involved. It includes the more specialized paleophytogeography and paleozoogeography subdisciplines.

The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of plants, fungi and algae from geological contexts, and their use for the biological reconstruction of past environments (paleogeography), as well as the evolutionary history of plants and allied kingdoms, with a bearing upon the evolution of life in general. These fossils can be impressions or compressions of the plants left on the rock's surface, or 'petrified' objects, such as wood, which preserve the original plant material in rocklike form.

The study of climates prior to the period of instrumental records, and of the causes of their variation, on either a local, regional or worldwide basis. It uses a variety of proxy methods from the Earth and life sciences to obtain data preserved within rocks, sediments, ice sheets, tree rings, corals, shells, and microfossils to determine the past states of the Earth's various climate regions and its atmospheric system.

A subdiscipline of paleontology concerned with reconstructing past biota, populations, communities, landscapes, environments, and ecosystems from available geological and biological (fossil) evidence. It encompasses the study of interactions between organisms and/or interactions between organisms and their environments across geological timescales, including reconstructions of past ecosystems and environments using this information.
The reconstruction of past environments and their climates within regions or across regions, based on the sediments, soils, strata, and associated biological remains.

The dating of geological materials by comparing the magnetic signature in rocks to known changes in the Earth's magnetic field (based on movements of the magnetic north pole over geological time). It is based on matching the changes in the paleomagnetic field recorded in lava flows or sediments with their corresponding dates in the magnetic polarity time scale. When applied to archeology, it is referred to as archeomagnetics.

The study of natural remanent magnetization of Earth materials (rocks, sediments and archeological materials) in order to determine the direction, and indirectly intensity, of the Earth's magnetic field in the geological past.

The scientific study of life in the geological past through the analysis of fossils, including those of microscopic size, and of traces representing preserved behaviour, preserved in rocks. It is concerned with all aspects of the biology of ancient life forms: their shape and structure, evolutionary patterns, taxonomic relationships with each other and with modern living species, geographic distribution, and interrelationships with the environment.

Originally, the study of pollen and spores, extant and fossil (paleopalynology), including stratigraphic and paleoecological applications. Now includes the study of a wide range of other robust-walled, acid-insoluble microscopic remains of various plants, animals, fungal spores and protists, including kerogen and unidentifiable organic matter.
The detection of natural low frequency earth movements, commonly with the purpose of discerning geological structures and locating underground oil, gas, or other resources.

One of the disciplines of soil science, pedology is the study of soil morphology, genesis, and classification. Pedometrics specifically refers to the use of quantitative methods for the study of soil distribution and genesis.

That branch of geology dealing with the description and systematic classification of rocks and especially by means of microscopic examination of thin sections. Petrography is more restricted in scope than petrology and overlaps considerably with mineralogy.

The fields of engineering concerned with activities related to the production of hydrocarbons to determine the way in which a reservoir is developed and depleted, i.e. the study and application of scientific and engineering principles to the fluid flow through a porous medium during the development and production of oil and gas reservoirs so as to obtain a high economic recovery.

The characterization of the physical properties and elemental analysis of oil and gas, used to interpret the type of source rock and correlate to a source rock, determine the thermal maturity of the oil and gas (and hence the maturity of the source rock), potential dating of the source rock, and compare oil and gas composition between different fields or within a field.

Study of the mode of origin and conditions of accumulation of hydrocarbons in the Earth's crust; their exploration, involving application of the techniques of geophysics, geochemistry, paleontology, stratigraphy, and tectonics; and their evaluation. It includes the assessment of petroleum systems and their composite parts: source, migration pathways, reservoir, seal, and method of entrapment.
That branch of geology dealing with the origin, occurrence, structure, and history of rocks, including the conditions under which they form. Petrology is broader in scope than petrography.

The study of the physical and chemical properties of rocks in relation to their interaction with fluids. A major application of petrophysics is in studying reservoirs for the hydrocarbon industry (especially the distribution of the pore system and its contained hydrocarbons and water).

The study of the physical and mechanical properties of rocks. Petrophysics focuses on how the microstructure of porous geological materials affects their mechanical, electrical, thermal, fluid flow, and sonic properties. Rock mechanics considers the mechanical or geomechanical properties of rocks, including reservoir strength, elastic properties, hardness, ultrasonic behaviour, index characteristics, and in situ stresses.

The science and technology of collecting/measuring, processing, analysing and interpreting information from noncontact imaging and other sensor systems that record the interaction between electromagnetic energy and matter, i.e. the acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon by using a recording device that is not in physical contact with the subject being studied. Aerial photographs and imagery acquired from a satellite or drone are examples of remotely sensed information.

An approach to systematics (the study of the kinds and diversity of organisms and the relationships between them) that attempts to recover the phylogenetic (genealogical) relationships among groups of organisms, and produces classifications that reflect exactly those genealogical relationships.

The branch of natural science which deals with the classification, form, processes, extent and patterns of natural phenomena in the natural environment such as the atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and geosphere. It differs chiefly from geology in that it considers conditions of the Earth primarily over shorter time scales (e.g. Quaternary and/or modern rates). It is more inclusive than geomorphology, dealing not only with landforms but also climate, oceans, atmosphere, soils, geologic processes, natural resources, and the biogeographical distribution of animal and plant life.

@graph.prefLabel: physical geography and environmental geoscience not elsewhere classified
@graph.definition: Physical geographical and environmental science data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of physical geography.

The systematic study of the inorganic world, as distinct from the study of the organic world, which is the province of biological science. Physical science is ordinarily thought of as consisting of four broad areas: astronomy, physics, chemistry, and the Earth sciences. Each of these is in turn divided into fields and subfields.

Public administration is the planning, preparation, and execution of policy meant to build and strengthen civil society. Policy, in this context, refers to prudence or wisdom in the management of affairs, or management procedures based primarily on material interest.

The field search for valuable commodities, mineral specimens (e.g. gold nuggets, crystals), lapidary material, and mineral deposits — usually with the ultimate objective of economic development by mining operations. Prospectors may be divided into two general categories: those with academic, scientific training and those with only field training or in the purely amateur category.

A predictive tool typically used for mineral exploration targeting at the broad regional- to camp-scale. It is less effective and less frequently used at the project- to deposit-scale where predictive tools compete with direct detection techniques. It includes the delineation of prospective areas based on personal experience and interpretation of available geological, geochemical and geophysical data, as well as statistical data analysis/modelling, and in combination GIS-based spatial datasets and/or soft computational models (e.g. fuzzy logic).

A discipline focused on the quantitative measurements of the mineralogy, chemistry, morphology and microstructures of minerals and mineral assemblages using a range of analytical techniques (e.g. modal analysis, X-ray diffractometry, infrared and Raman spectroscopy, refractometry, spectral mapping, etc.). Specifically, quantitative mineral methodologies are utilized to measure and/or constrain mineral abundances, as well as to provide mineral grade and texture information for geological and mineral processing applications.

The study of industrial mineral resources, i.e. geological materials that are mined/quarried for their commercial value and are not fuel (fuel minerals or mineral fuels) or sources of metals (metallic minerals) but are used in their natural state or after beneficiation either as raw materials or as additives in a wide range of applications based on their physical and/or chemical properties. These studies include the quantification of the physical properties, chemical properties, volumes, and limitations to development of quarry products. Quarry resources (also referred to as basic raw materials or industrial minerals) include, but may not be limited to, sand (including silica sand), clay, hard rock (including dimension stone), limestone (including metallurgical limestone), agricultural lime, gravel, gypsum, other construction and road building materials and materials which may substitute these raw materials.

The branch of geology that study environmental changes from 2.58 million years ago to the present. In particular, Quaternary geology study the process and deposits that developed during the Quaternary, a period characterized by glacial–interglacial cycles.

The branch of geochronology / isotope geochemistry focusing on radiogenic isotope systems, i.e. those where a daughter isotope is produced from the decay of a radioactive parent isotope, to determine the numerical age of suitable geological materials.

The dating of geological materials by using the effects of radioactivity other than the natural decay from a parent to a daughter isotope. It includes methods such as fission tracks (measure of the density of track marking left in a material by the spontaneous fission of uranium-238 impurities), luminescence (measure of the effect of background radiation on certain minerals), and electron spin resonance (ESR), measure of the amount of unpaired electrons in crystalline structures that were previously exposed to natural radiation). The term radiogenic here is used as in Colman et al. (1987).
The branch of isotope geochemistry focusing on radiogenic isotope systems, i.e. those where a daughter isotope is produced from the decay of a radioactive parent isotope.
The radiometric, or gamma-ray spectrometric method is a geophysical process used to estimate concentrations of the radioelements potassium, uranium and thorium in the near surface.
The geological study of large-scale regions, providing a link between global and local geology, and a framework for site-specific studies.

The mineralogical study of specific geographic regions, from ore deposits clusters to large metallogenic provinces. It includes evaluation of location and the spatial distribution of minerals and mineral assemblages in relation to the geological history of the province (region) or the formation of the deposit. Regional mineralogy can include mineral regional fingerprinting, and directly links to metallogeny and genetic mineralogy.

The study of the geology of surficial deposits, i.e. those at or near the Earth's surface. It includes the study of soils and unconsolidated sediments, their geological features and structures, and their relationships to the underlying bedrock.

The study of the chemical composition of materials and components making up the surficial, weathered, and usually unconsolidated layer that nearly everywhere forms the surface of the land and overlies or covers the bedrock. Regolith includes rock debris of all kinds, volcanic ash, glacial drift, alluvium, loess and eolian deposits, vegetal accumulations, and soil.

The stage in the life-cycle of a project or mine where the resources have been extracted and the site or part thereof is being rehabilitated back to its original condition or an acceptable environmental standard.

Geoscience studies related to the definition and exploitation of energy derived from natural resources such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat, that are replenished either through natural reproduction or other recurring processes in a finite amount of time on a human time scale.

A characterization of a reservoir that incorporates all the characteristics of the reservoir that are pertinent to its ability to store hydrocarbons and also to produce them. Reservoir characterization models are used to simulate the behaviour of the fluids within the reservoir under different sets of circumstances and to find the optimal production techniques that will maximize the production. Typically, a reservoir analysis incorporates interpretation of depositional facies and diagenesis, mineralogical and textural maturity parameters obtained from macro/meso (e.g. cores, sidewall cores, cuttings) and micro (e.g. thin sections, scanning electron microscope work) samples, as well as direct and indirect measurements of porosity, permeability and grain density from well log analysis and core and mechanical sidewall cores. Image logs are used to determine fracture density where applicable. Regional reservoir distribution and thickness is derived from multiple well reservoir data, seismic interpretation and depth mapping.
The study of fuels, metals and other materials of economic interest; it is concerned with the distribution, value and availability of resources, and the cost and benefits of their recovery.
