Engineering that applies various branches of science in order to create new technology that aims to protect, maintain, extract, and establish sustainable natural resources.

A theoretical and applied science of the physical behaviour of rocks and rock masses. In relation to geology, it is the branch of mechanics concerned with the response of rock and rock masses to the force fields of their physical environment.
Remotely sensed spectral imaging obtained from a platform in orbit outside the atmosphere of Earth.

The use of satellites to determine the location (geographic position) of a receiver on Earth. The technique involves measuring the range between the receiver and the satellite, and the range measurement used to calculate the receiver's position using observation equations and least squares. The technique is used in global and regional satellite navigation systems.

A characterization of regional caprocks and intraformational barriers (seals) to understand their capacity to trap fluids (oil, gas, etc.); specifically to determine seal capacity (i.e. the capillary pressure, or column height, at which a trapped fluid commences to leak through a seal rock) and conduct fault seal analysis (a measure of the capacity of a fault to leak or seal hydrocarbons).
The study of the composition, characteristics, occurrence, and origin of sediments and sedimentary rocks.
The scientific study of sedimentary rocks and of the processes by which they were formed; the description, classification, origin, and interpretation of sediments.

The study of stratigraphy and depositional facies as interpreted from seismic data; an integrated stratigraphic and sedimentologic technique to interpret seismic reflection data for stratigraphic correlation and to predict depositional environments and lithology.
The science of the acquisition, processing, and analysis of seismic datasets measured and recorded with reference to a particular area of the Earth's surface, to evaluate the subsurface.

Seismic tomography is a technique for imaging the subsurface of the Earth with seismic waves produced by controlled ‘active’ sources such as vibrations or explosions, or natural ‘passive’ sources such as earthquakes, wind, waves or human activity. P-, S-, and surface waves can be used for tomographic models of different resolutions based on seismic wavelength, wave source distance, and the seismograph array coverage. The data received at seismometers are used to solve an inverse problem, wherein the locations of reflection and refraction of the wave paths are determined. This solution can be used to create 3D images of velocity anomalies which may be interpreted as structural, thermal, or compositional variations.

The scientific study of earthquakes and the propagation of elastic waves both natural and artificially generated through the Earth or through other planetary bodies. The field also includes studies of earthquake environmental effects such as tsunamis as well as diverse seismic sources such as volcanic, tectonic, oceanic, atmospheric, and artificial processes such as explosions. Seismic exploration is a method of exploration geophysics that uses the principles of seismology to estimate the properties of the Earth's subsurface from artificially generated seismic waves.

The study of rock relationships within a chronostratigraphic framework of repetitive, genetically related strata bounded by surfaces of erosion or nondeposition, or their correlative conformities (Van Wagoner et al., 1990). Specifically, a field of study in which basin-filling sedimentary deposits, called sequences, are interpreted in a framework of eustasy, sedimentation and subsidence through time in order to correlate strata and predict the stratigraphy of relatively unknown areas.

The study of the chemical composition of the unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the surface of the earth that serves as a natural medium for the growth of land plants, and whose formation is conditioned by relief and controlled by genetic and environmental factors such as climate (including water and temperature effects) and biological activity (macro- and micro-organisms) acting on parent material over a period of time.

The science dealing with soils as a natural resource on the surface of the Earth including (a) soil formation, soil classification and mapping; (b) physical, chemical, biological, and fertility properties of soils per se; and (c) these properties in relation to the use and management of soils.
The evaluation of the lithological sources of hydrocarbons, i.e. those rocks which contain organic matter and are (or have been) generating and/or expelling hydrocarbons to form accumulations.

The use of multiple bands across the electromagnetic spectrum to create a dataset that contains many images of the same object, where each one of them is measured at a different wavelength. It includes multispectral imaging that typically captures three to fifteen spectral bands, and hyperspectral imaging that combines spectroscopy and digital photography to capture hundreds of wavelength bands.

The exploration and scientific study of caves and other karst features, both physical and biological, including their composition and mineralogy, structure (morphology), physical properties, history, ecology, and the processes by which they form (speleogenesis) and change over time (speleomorphology).
The systematic identification, analysis, planning, and implementation of actions designed to influence stakeholders. This process identifies the needs of key groups and ensures those needs are met.

The study of the history, composition, relative ages and distribution of strata, and the interpretation of strata to elucidate Earth's history. The comparison, or correlation, of separated strata can include study of their form, distribution, lithology, fossil content, geophysical and geochemical properties, relative or numerical/absolute age, and their interpretation in terms of environment or mode of origin, and geological history.

The branch of geology that deals with the form (geometry), spatial arrangement, and internal structure of the rocks, and especially with the description, representation, and analysis of structures (e.g. bedding, folds, faults and fractures), chiefly on a meso- to macroscopic scale. The subject is similar to tectonics, but the latter is generally used for the broader regional or historical phases.

The branches of geology that, combined, focus on the manifestation of plate tectonic motions in the deformation of Earth's crust and lithosphere, from the scale of mountain ranges to individual faults and folds, and on timescales from deep Earth history to present-day tectonism and associated natural hazards.

The study of the form, physical properties, composition, function, and evolution of Earth’s surface, a dynamic interface where physical, chemical, biological, and human processes cause and are affected by forces in the Earth system, with impact-feedback loops that occur over a wide range of temporal and spatial scales.

The subfield of hydrology concerned with above-earth water, in contrast to groundwater hydrology that deals with water below the surface of the Earth. Its applications include rainfall and runoff, the routes that surface water takes (for example through rivers or reservoirs), and the occurrence of floods and droughts.

The applied science of determining the two-dimensional or three-dimensional positions of points necessary to determine the area of any part of the Earth's (or other planetary body) surface, the lengths and directions of the boundary lines, and the contour of the surface, and of accurately delineating the whole on paper/digitally.
The branch of paleontology concerned with all processes occurring after the death of an organism until its discovery. It includes biostratonomy and fossil diagenesis.

The theory and practice of identifying, describing, naming, and classifying organisms. The terms taxonomy and systematics are usually distinguished, the latter having broader connotation, but they may also be used more or less synonymously.

The branch of geology dealing with the broad architecture of the outer part of the Earth, i.e. the regional assembling of structural or deformational features, a study of their mutual relations, origin and historical evolution. It is closely related to structural geology, with which the distinctions are blurred, but tectonics generally deals with larger features.

The collection, preparation, petrographic description, and approximate dating of tephra. The technique uses discrete layers of tephra (volcanic ash from a single eruption) to create a chronological framework in which paleoenvironmental or archeological records can be placed. The premise of the technique is that each volcanic event produces ash with a unique chemical 'fingerprint' that allows the deposit to be identified across the area affected by fallout. Thus, once the volcanic event has been independently dated, the tephra horizon will act as time marker (as such it is a variant of the basic geological technique of stratigraphy).

The study of the thermal evolution of a region of a planet. Thermochronologists use radiometric dating (the determination of the age of a sample based on the rate of decay of a radioactive nuclide) along with closure temperatures (i.e. the temperature of the mineral being studied at the time given by the date recorded) to understand the thermal history of a specific rock, mineral, or geological unit.

The non-destructive, three-dimensional characterization of earth and planetary materials that uses material-penetrating energy sources. Tomography methods in Earth Science include experiments in controlled laboratory settings such as computed tomography of rock samples or soils, and field experiments such as seismic tomography of the Solid Earth.

The geological study of unconventional petroleum systems, which comprise formations with tight gas, tight oil, oil sands, oil shale, bitumen, gas shales, coal seam gas/coalbed methane, and gas hydrates, and are defined as those where petroleum is distributed throughout the reservoir at basin-wide scale and in which buoyant forces or the influence of a water column on the location of hydrocarbons in the reservoir are not significant.

Urban planning, also known as town planning, city planning, regional planning, or rural planning in specific contexts, is a technical and political process that is focused on the development and design of land use and the built environment, including air, water, and the infrastructure passing into and out of urban areas, such as transportation, communications, and distribution networks, and their accessibility. Traditionally, urban planning followed a top-down approach in master planning the physical layout of human settlements, with a primary focus on public welfare (i.e. considerations of efficiency, sanitation, protection and use of the environment) as well as effects of the master plans on the social and economic activities. Over time, urban planning's focus has shifted to social and environmental factors to be a tool to improve the health and well-being of people while maintaining sustainability standards.

The application of geological knowledge and principles to the planning and management of cities and their surroundings. It includes geological studies for physical planning, waste disposal, land use, water-resources management, and extraction of usable raw materials.

A dating method that utilizes the seasonal (summer and winter) sedimentological variations of deposits in lakes that undergo an annual freeze-up, by counting and measuring thicknesses in annual paired layers of sediments. Because each year’s sediment accumulation varies in thickness according to the climatic conditions of the melt season, any long sequence of varve measurements provides a distinctive 'signature' and can be correlated for moderate distances from lake basin to lake basin. Counting and correlation of varves have been used to measure the ages of Pleistocene glacial deposits.

The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of Phylum Chordata. This includes modern vertebrates, non-vertebrate chordates (such as lancets and turnicates), and extinct groups of uncertain placement (such as conodonts).
The branch of geology that deals with volcanism (e.g. volcanoes, lava, magma), its causes and related geological, geophysical and geochemical phenomena.
